content: The "Track It to Prevent It Act" is the short title of the Act, with a table of contents provided. The "Track It to Prevent It Act" includes findings, definitions, improved climate assessments, inclusion of disciplinary actions, service-wide assessments, health welfare inspections, security reviews, diversity management role in sexual harassment cases, and authorization of appropriations. SEC. 2. FINDINGS. Congress finds that in fiscal year 2012, there was a 6 percent increase in reported sexual assault cases involving members of the Armed Forces. Additionally, approximately 26,000 members made anonymous reports of sexual assault, a significant rise from the previous year. Among female members, 6.1 percent experienced unwanted sexual contact, with 77 percent reporting such incidents. In fiscal year 2012, there was a substantial increase in reported sexual assault cases involving members of the Armed Forces. Among female members, 6.1 percent experienced unwanted sexual contact, with 77 percent also experiencing sexual harassment. Additionally, 62 percent of those who experienced unwanted sexual contact perceived some form of retaliation. In fiscal year 2012, 52 percent of individuals who experienced unwanted sexual contact also faced sexual harassment. Additionally, 62 percent of those individuals perceived some form of retaliation. Commanders must comply with climate assessments to create a safe environment and identify trends in harmful behavior like sexual harassment and assault. In order to create a safe environment for the unit, trends in harmful behavior such as sexual harassment and assault must be identified earlier through improved performance assessments and better reporting by commanders at all levels. Members often choose not to report incidents due to a lack of belief that action will be taken or fear of repercussions. Members often do not report sexual harassment and assault incidents in the military because they believe nothing will be done about it and fear it will harm their career. Commanders' tolerance or ignorance of such misconduct perpetuates this behavior, hindering cultural change. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "sexual harassment" and "sexual assault" according to Department of Defense directives. SEC. 4. IMPROVED CLIMATE ASSESSMENTS AND DISSEMINATION AND TRACKING OF RESULTS. The Secretary of Defense must ensure that command climate assessment results are shared with relevant commanders and higher levels of command. Each military department must include a designated form in performance evaluations for senior commanders to indicate if required climate assessments have been conducted. Failure to conduct assessments will have consequences. The Secretary must provide a designated form for senior commanders to indicate if climate assessments have been conducted. Failure to do so will impact the commander's performance evaluation and promotion consideration. The Inspector General will develop a tracking system to monitor assessment compliance. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense will develop a tracking system to monitor whether commanders are conducting command climate assessments. Unit commanders, in collaboration with the Inspector General, will gather climate assessments and create compliance reports including concerns expressed by unit members, perceptions of leadership, and a strategic plan to address concerns. SEC. 5. INCLUSION OF LETTER OF REPRIMANDS, NONPUNITIVE LETTER OF REPRIMANDS AND COUNSELING STATEMENTS. The Secretary of Defense mandates commanders to include disciplinary actions related to sexual harassment or assault in the performance evaluations of Armed Forces members to increase visibility, identify trends of misconduct, and prevent the transfer of sexual offenders. Additionally, there is a provision for service-wide 360 assessments. The Secretary of each military department is required to develop a 360-degree assessment program and submit a report on its feasibility for inclusion in performance evaluations. Individual counseling is also mandated as part of the program. The feasibility of including the 360-degree approach in performance evaluations is being assessed. Individual counseling is mandated as part of the process. SEC. 7. HEALTH WELFARE INSPECTIONS. The Secretary of each military department conducts monthly health welfare inspections to ensure security, military readiness, and discipline. Results are provided to commanders. SEC. 8. REVIEW OF SECURITY OF MILITARY INSTALLATIONS, INCLUDING BARRACKS AND MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENCES. The Secretary of Defense will review security measures on military installations, focusing on barracks and multi-family residences to ensure the safety of Armed Forces members and their dependents. This includes identifying security gaps and evaluating the feasibility of 24-hour electronic monitoring or security personnel presence. The Secretary of Defense will identify security gaps on military installations and evaluate the feasibility of 24-hour electronic monitoring or security personnel at entry points into barracks and multi-family residences. A report with cost estimates to address security gaps must be submitted to Congress within 90 days. The Secretary of Defense will submit a report to Congress within 90 days, detailing the costs to eliminate security gaps and provide 24-hour security monitoring on military installations. SEC. 9. REVIEW OF THE OFFICE OF DIVERSITY MANAGEMENT AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY ROLE IN SEXUAL HARASSMENT CASES. The Secretary of Defense will review the Office of Diversity Management and Equal Opportunity to identify resource gaps, assess its role in sexual harassment cases, and evaluate its collaboration with the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Secretary of Defense for fiscal year 2014 to carry out the Act.
